message.content:
Step 1: Current Ratio  
• We use the End amounts from the balance sheet:  
 – Total Current Assets = 9,963,057.95  
 – Total Current Liabilities = 829,755.77  
• Current Ratio = 9,963,057.95 / 829,755.77 ≈ 12.01  

Step 2: Quick Ratio  
• Quick Assets = Current Assets – Inventory  
 – Inventory (End) = 720,000.00  
 – Quick Assets = 9,963,057.95 – 720,000.00 = 9,243,057.95  
• Quick Ratio = 9,243,057.95 / 829,755.77 ≈ 11.14  

Step 3: Debt to Asset Ratio  
• Total Debt is taken as Total Liabilities. From the balance sheet, since there are no other liabilities indicated:  
 – Total Liabilities = 829,755.77  
 – Total Assets = 15,023,526.85  
• Debt to Asset Ratio = 829,755.77 / 15,023,526.85 ≈ 0.055, which rounds to 0.06  

Step 4: Debt to Equity Ratio  
• Owner’s Equity (End) = 14,193,771.08  
• Debt to Equity Ratio = 829,755.77 / 14,193,771.08 ≈ 0.058, which rounds to 0.06  

Step 5: Cash Flow to Debt Ratio  
• From the cash flow statement, the Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities = –224,133.22  
• Total Debt (using Total Liabilities) = 829,755.77  
• Cash Flow to Debt Ratio = –224,133.22 / 829,755.77 ≈ –0.27  

Thus, the final computed ratios are:  
 Current Ratio: 12.01  
 Quick Ratio: 11.14  
 Debt to Asset Ratio: 0.06  
 Debt to Equity Ratio: 0.06  
 Cash Flow to Debt Ratio: –0.27  

Below is the answer in the requested json format:

{
  "solution": {
    "Current Ratio": "12.01",
    "Quick Ratio": "11.14",
    "Debt to Asset Ratio": "0.06",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.06",
    "Cash Flow to Debt Ratio": "-0.27"
  }
}
